title: RL34054
content: The FCC prepared to auction 62 MHz of radio frequencies in the 700 MHz band to comply with the Deficit Reduction Act. They proposed creating a public-private partnership to build a nationwide broadband network for public safety users by pairing 10 MHz of public safety spectrum with 10 MHz of auctionable spectrum. The FCC proposed a shared network of 20 MHz for a nationwide broadband network by pairing frequency bands with auctionable spectrum. This decision was based on the need for robust communications capabilities and interoperability in public safety, as well as the benefits of sharing spectrum with commercial users. A national license for 10 MHz was assigned to a not-for-profit corporation representing public safety interests. The FCC assigned a national license for 10 MHz to a not-for-profit corporation representing public safety interests. The public safety license was created from 24 MHz originally assigned to public safety. The FCC designated 10 MHz from commercial frequencies to be paired with public safety's 10 MHz to create a shared network. The commercial license, known as the D Block, attracted only one bidder at Auction 73, Qualcomm, Inc., with an opening bid of $472 million. The reserve price of $1.3 billion set by the FCC was not met, leading to the decision not to proceed with the re-auction of the D Block. The FCC did not proceed with the re-auction of the D Block after no other bidders met the reserve price of $1.3 billion. Instead, they initiated a review of rules regarding licensing and partnerships. New auction rules were laid out, offering a nationwide license for the Public Safety Broadband Licensee and commercial licenses either nationally or in smaller regions. The new auction rules for the D Block include modifications from Auction 73, offering a nationwide license for the Public Safety Broadband Licensee and commercial licenses nationally or in 58 regions. Key needs for an effective solution include sufficient spectrum (at least 20 MHz) and a source of funds. The report outlines three key needs for an effective solution: sufficient spectrum (at least 20 MHz) for a nationwide broadband network, a source of funds to cover costs associated with public safety, and a management structure for a public-private partnership. Additionally, it is assumed that commercial partners will utilize the shared network for consumer services. The D Block license failed to attract a winning bid due to various reasons, including flaws in the auction structure and rules that discouraged potential bidders. Possible solutions include modifying auction rules to eliminate FCC requirements that deter bidders while maintaining the public-private partnership. Another option is to eliminate the network sharing requirement, allowing public safety to negotiate independently for partnerships, and auction the license without public safety requirements. These solutions aim to attract bidders while ensuring the structure of the partnership remains intact. These solutions aim to maintain the partnership structure while enabling successful collaboration for public safety interoperability.
